video.title: JavaScript DOM Manipulation – Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn about JavaScript DOM manipulation in this beginner's tutorial. This is when you use JavaScript to add, remove, and modify elements of a website. 

In the first part of the course, you will learn about the basic features of a website DOM and the JavaScript commands you can use to manipulate the DOM. In the second part of the course, you will use what you have learned to create practical examples ranging from beginner to advanced. 

✏️ CodeLab created this course. Check out their channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/CodeLab98

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:01:32) What is the DOM?
⌨️ (0:02:05) DOM Tree Analogy 
⌨️ (0:04:01) Selecting Elements in the DOM
⌨️ (0:11:44) Styling an Element
⌨️ (0:16:33) Creating Elements
⌨️ (0:17:32) Adding Elements 
⌨️ (0:18:33) Modify Text
⌨️ (0:21:15) Modifying Elements Attributes & Classes
⌨️ (0:24:59) Remove an Element
⌨️ (0:25:47) DOM Tree Recap
⌨️ (0:27:58) Traversing the DOM
⌨️ (0:37:48) Event Listeners 
⌨️ (0:44:59) Event Listener Example
⌨️ (0:50:16) Event Propagation
⌨️ (1:00:07) Event Delegation
⌨️ (1:11:13) Introduction to Projects
⌨️ (1:11:52) Project 1: Beginner
⌨️ (1:14:26) Project 1 Mark-Up
⌨️ (1:16:31) General Styles for All Projects
⌨️ (1:17:08) Project 1 CSS Styling
⌨️ (1:24:40) Project 1 JavaScript
⌨️ (1:29:39) Project 2: Beginner + 
⌨️ (1:30:41) Project 2 Mark Up
⌨️ (1:32:33) Project 2 CSS styling
⌨️ (1:41:30) Project 2 JavaScript
⌨️ (1:46:08) Project 2 CSS Styling p2
⌨️ (1:47:53) Project 3: Intermediate 
⌨️ (1:48:39) Project 3 Mark Up
⌨️ (1:49:59) Project 3 CSS Styling
⌨️ (1:55:19) Project 3 JavaScript
⌨️ (1:58:02) Project 3 CSS Styling p2
⌨️ (2:00:45) Project 4: Pro
⌨️ (2:01:26) Project 4 Mark Up
⌨️ (2:02:44) Project 4 CSS Styling
⌨️ (2:06:36) Project 4 JavaScript 
⌨️ (2:20:37) Project 5: Master
⌨️ (2:22:01) Project 5 Mark Up
⌨️ (2:23:15) Project 5 CSS Styling
⌨️ (2:26:39) Project 5 JavaScript
⌨️ (2:33:52) Project 5 CSS Styling p2
⌨️ (2:38:41) Project 5 JavaScript p2

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: BlackZero Rs
topLevelComment.text:
This is the very basic tutorial for beginners. But stop messing with css if your focus is on the DOM. Also, this is barely touched 5% of DOM stuff. DOM is way more complex. They need
- Accessing parent element using closest method.
- Placing onclick and other events inline from html to javascript
- Template literals html insertion
- Template components from loops
- Accessing/selecting specific child from js
- Nested querySelector by any attribute, class or tag
- Find elements by any attributes or tag or class
- class toggle, replace, add, remove
- Get elements coordinates
- Move elements in the dom
- style elements from js
- modify css variables from js
- teach new guys how to discover any element methods three using console.dir(element)
- get computed css style of specific element
- working with touch events, building swiper or carousel
# I can list things all day long. But stop mess with css. Just prepare the classes and manage them through the JS and DOM.

topLevelComment.author: Rahul Jindal
topLevelComment.text:
Hey CodeLabs, Thanks for the course. 
I have a question at 1:11:00 , so here first event listener is added to the unordered list(existing list items). then we append one list item(rugby) to ul. So, when we append, is it refreshing the page to get in sync or what is doing behind the scenes? I'm not getting it. Like ul knows that new element(rugby) is appended, so how ul comes to know that it needs to apply all the functionalities defined in app.js?

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text: He's using live server extension in VSCode which automatically reloads the webpage when the source code is modified. This has nothing to do with the JavaScript code itself.

topLevelComment.author: Shade Storm
topLevelComment.text:
25:10

i usually use includes() method to check for existing classes in the classList
but here we  contains() method is being used which I did not know about, 
upon checking the web it says contains() method is not part of vanilla JS...
so what's going on??

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
Element.classList is an array-like object of class DOMTokenList and it doesn't have Array methods.
DOMTokenList.contains() is functionally the same as Array.includes()

topLevelComment.author: Lyn Paine
topLevelComment.text: How did you make the index.html file? Is that already made? Or you have to create it first,  I'm kinda lost.

replies.author: Nicholas B
replies.text: ​@Lyn Paine One good place to start with html, css, etc.: "code stackr Web Development For Beginners (Start Here)" and you should see a playlist. I'd practice writing code in notepad or other text editor too once in a while to remember code without depending on an IDE like VS Code. If you interested in what to learn the roadmap in the first vid helps. Searching for an "introduction to ???" may be good too if ya want a different course. Good luck on your journey

replies.author: Lyn Paine
replies.text: @Nicholas B  thank you so much. I might jump to far from this topic. I'm a beginner, do you have suggestions where to start?

replies.author: Vs Sm
replies.text: @Nicholas B you can open any website in browser dev tools and see all the files.

replies.author: Vs Sm
replies.text: Open any simple text editor, type something in, save it as index.html on your machine. Now you can open it in any browser.

replies.author: Nicholas B
replies.text:
He made a file called index.html and put all that code in there. There's probably also an style.css file too but I haven't looked at the video enough. It would be nice to have the source of the code idk where it is.

And also it doesn't have to be called index.html it just needs to have .html at the end. So for example list-of-💛pineapples.html would work
